questions.question_text: Amino acids are classified as α-amino acids because:
options: A. They are the first amino acids discovered
B. The amino group is on the alpha carbon (adjacent to carboxyl)
C. They have one amino group
questions.explanation: α-Amino acids have the amino group attached to the carbon adjacent to (alpha to) the carboxylic acid group.

questions.question_text: At physiological pH (~7.4), most amino acids exist as:
options: B. Zwitterions with charged amino and carboxyl groups
questions.explanation: At physiological pH, the amino group is protonated (NH3+, pKa ~9) and the carboxyl is deprotonated (COO-, pKa ~2), creating a zwitterion.

questions.question_text: The isoelectric point (pI) of a simple amino acid is:
options: A. The pH where it is most soluble
B. The pH where it has no net charge
C. The pH where it denatures
questions.explanation: The pI is the pH at which the amino acid has no net electrical charge, calculated as the average of the two pKa values for simple amino acids.

questions.question_text: All naturally occurring amino acids in proteins (except glycine) are:
questions.explanation: Proteins are made of L-amino acids. Glycine is achiral (R=H). The L-configuration corresponds to S-configuration for most amino acids.

questions.question_text: Peptide bond formation between amino acids involves:
options: B. Amide bond formation with loss of water
questions.explanation: A peptide bond is an amide bond formed by condensation between the carboxyl group of one amino acid and the amino group of another, releasing water.

questions.question_text: Peptide bonds have partial double-bond character due to:
options: B. Resonance delocalization of the nitrogen lone pair
questions.explanation: The nitrogen lone pair delocalizes into the carbonyl, giving the C-N bond partial double-bond character and restricting rotation.

questions.question_text: Protein primary structure refers to:
options: A. Alpha helices and beta sheets
B. The linear sequence of amino acids
questions.explanation: Primary structure is the linear sequence of amino acids in a polypeptide chain, determined by the gene encoding the protein.

questions.question_text: Protein secondary structure includes:
options: B. Alpha helices, beta sheets, and turns
questions.explanation: Secondary structure refers to local folding patterns (α-helices, β-sheets, turns) stabilized by hydrogen bonds between backbone atoms.

questions.question_text: Alpha helices are stabilized by hydrogen bonds between:
options: B. C=O of residue n and N-H of residue n+4
questions.explanation: In α-helices, hydrogen bonds form between the carbonyl oxygen of one residue and the amide hydrogen four residues ahead along the chain.

questions.question_text: Beta sheets are formed by hydrogen bonds between:
options: A. Residues within the same strand
B. Backbone atoms of adjacent strands
D. The N and C termini
questions.explanation: β-sheets are formed by hydrogen bonds between backbone C=O and N-H groups of adjacent polypeptide strands (parallel or antiparallel).

questions.question_text: Protein tertiary structure refers to:
options: C. The overall 3D shape of a single polypeptide
questions.explanation: Tertiary structure is the complete three-dimensional arrangement of all atoms in a single polypeptide chain.

questions.question_text: Forces stabilizing tertiary structure include all EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: Tertiary structure is stabilized by side chain interactions (hydrophobic, disulfide, ionic, H-bonds). Peptide bonds define primary structure.

questions.question_text: Disulfide bonds form between two residues of:
questions.explanation: Disulfide bonds (S-S) form by oxidation of the thiol groups of two cysteine residues, creating covalent cross-links.

questions.question_text: Quaternary structure involves:
options: C. Multiple polypeptide subunits associated together
questions.explanation: Quaternary structure describes the arrangement of multiple polypeptide subunits (oligomer) in proteins with more than one chain.

questions.question_text: Carbohydrates have the general formula:
questions.explanation: Carbohydrates have the general formula Cn(H2O)n, appearing as hydrates of carbon (hence the name), though this is coincidental.

questions.question_text: Monosaccharides are classified by:
options: B. Number of carbons and whether aldose or ketose
questions.explanation: Monosaccharides are classified by carbon number (triose, tetrose, pentose, hexose) and functional group (aldose=aldehyde, ketose=ketone).

questions.question_text: Glucose is classified as an:
questions.explanation: Glucose is an aldohexose: it has six carbons (hexose) and an aldehyde functional group (aldose).

questions.question_text: Fructose is classified as a:
questions.explanation: Fructose is a ketohexose: it has six carbons (hexose) and a ketone functional group (ketose).

questions.question_text: D and L designations for sugars are based on:
options: B. Configuration at the highest-numbered chiral carbon
questions.explanation: D/L designation is based on the configuration at the highest-numbered chiral carbon (typically penultimate carbon) compared to D/L-glyceraldehyde.

questions.question_text: Epimers are sugars that differ in configuration at:
questions.explanation: Epimers are diastereomers that differ at only one chiral center. For example, glucose and galactose are C-4 epimers.

questions.question_text: When glucose cyclizes, the new chiral center formed is called the:
questions.explanation: Cyclization creates a new stereocenter at C-1 (for aldoses), called the anomeric carbon. It can be α or β configuration.

questions.question_text: Anomers differ in configuration at:
questions.explanation: Anomers are isomers that differ only at the anomeric carbon (α and β forms), created during cyclization of sugars.

questions.question_text: Mutarotation is:
options: B. Interconversion of anomers through the open-chain form
questions.explanation: Mutarotation is the change in optical rotation as α and β anomers interconvert through the open-chain form until equilibrium is reached.

questions.question_text: A glycosidic bond is formed between:
options: B. The anomeric carbon of one sugar and an OH of another
questions.explanation: A glycosidic bond is an acetal linkage between the anomeric carbon of one sugar and a hydroxyl group of another molecule (sugar or aglycone).

questions.question_text: Reducing sugars can reduce Tollens' or Fehling's reagent because they:
options: B. Have a free anomeric carbon that can open to an aldehyde
questions.explanation: Reducing sugars have a free anomeric carbon that can open to the aldehyde form, which can be oxidized (reducing the metal ion).

questions.question_text: Sucrose is NOT a reducing sugar because:
options: B. Both anomeric carbons are involved in the glycosidic bond
questions.explanation: In sucrose, the glycosidic bond links the anomeric carbons of both glucose and fructose, leaving no free anomeric carbon to open.

questions.question_text: Starch and glycogen are both:
options: B. Polymers of glucose with α-glycosidic bonds
C. Polymers of glucose with β-glycosidic bonds
questions.explanation: Both starch and glycogen are storage polysaccharides made of glucose units linked by α-1,4 glycosidic bonds (with α-1,6 branches).

questions.question_text: Cellulose differs from starch in having:
options: B. β-1,4 glycosidic bonds instead of α-1,4
questions.explanation: Cellulose has β-1,4 glycosidic bonds, making it indigestible by humans (we lack β-glucosidase). Starch has α-1,4 bonds.

questions.question_text: Lipids are characterized by being:
questions.explanation: Lipids are a diverse group of biomolecules defined by their solubility in nonpolar solvents rather than water.

questions.question_text: Triglycerides are:
options: B. Tri-esters of glycerol with fatty acids
questions.explanation: Triglycerides (triacylglycerols) consist of glycerol esterified with three fatty acid chains.

questions.question_text: Saturated fatty acids have:
options: A. One or more double bonds
questions.explanation: Saturated fatty acids contain no C=C double bonds; all carbons are 'saturated' with hydrogen atoms.

questions.question_text: Unsaturated fatty acids have lower melting points than saturated fatty acids because:
options: B. Cis double bonds create kinks that reduce packing
questions.explanation: Cis double bonds in unsaturated fatty acids create kinks that prevent tight packing, reducing intermolecular forces and melting points.

questions.question_text: Phospholipids differ from triglycerides by having:
options: B. A phosphate group replacing one fatty acid
questions.explanation: Phospholipids have two fatty acid chains and a phosphate-containing group attached to glycerol, making them amphipathic.

questions.question_text: Phospholipids are amphipathic, meaning they have:
options: C. Both hydrophobic and hydrophilic regions
D. Neither hydrophobic nor hydrophilic properties
questions.explanation: Phospholipids are amphipathic: the fatty acid tails are hydrophobic while the phosphate head group is hydrophilic.

questions.question_text: In aqueous solution, phospholipids spontaneously form:
questions.explanation: The amphipathic nature of phospholipids drives self-assembly into bilayers (membranes) or micelles in water.

questions.question_text: Steroids are characterized by:
options: B. Four fused rings (three six-membered and one five-membered)
questions.explanation: Steroids have a characteristic four-ring structure (steroid nucleus) consisting of three cyclohexane rings and one cyclopentane ring fused together.

questions.question_text: Cholesterol is a:
questions.explanation: Cholesterol is a steroid lipid that is essential for membrane structure and serves as a precursor for steroid hormones and bile acids.

questions.question_text: Nucleotides consist of:
options: A. Amino acid, sugar, and phosphate
B. Nitrogenous base, sugar, and phosphate
C. Fatty acid, glycerol, and phosphate
questions.explanation: Nucleotides have three components: a nitrogenous base (purine or pyrimidine), a pentose sugar (ribose or deoxyribose), and one or more phosphate groups.

questions.question_text: The purines in DNA and RNA are:
questions.explanation: Purines (adenine and guanine) have two fused rings. Pyrimidines (cytosine, thymine, uracil) have one ring.

questions.question_text: DNA and RNA differ in that DNA has:
questions.explanation: DNA contains deoxyribose (2'-deoxy) and thymine, while RNA has ribose (2'-OH) and uracil instead of thymine.

questions.question_text: The phosphodiester backbone of DNA connects:
options: B. The 5' carbon of one nucleotide to the 3' carbon of the next
questions.explanation: Phosphodiester bonds link the 5'-phosphate of one nucleotide to the 3'-hydroxyl of the next, creating the sugar-phosphate backbone.

questions.question_text: Base pairing in DNA involves:
questions.explanation: Watson-Crick base pairing: adenine pairs with thymine (2 H-bonds) and guanine pairs with cytosine (3 H-bonds).

questions.question_text: The two strands of DNA are:
questions.explanation: DNA strands run antiparallel (5'→3' opposite 3'→5') and are complementary through specific base pairing.

questions.question_text: ATP is classified as a:
questions.explanation: ATP (adenosine triphosphate) is a ribonucleoside triphosphate consisting of adenine, ribose, and three phosphate groups.

questions.question_text: The high energy of ATP comes from:
questions.explanation: The closely-spaced negative charges on the phosphate groups create electrostatic repulsion, making the phosphoanhydride bonds high-energy.

questions.question_text: Saponification of a triglyceride produces:
options: B. Glycerol and fatty acid salts (soap)
questions.explanation: Saponification (base-catalyzed hydrolysis) of triglycerides produces glycerol and the sodium or potassium salts of fatty acids (soaps).

questions.question_text: Hemoglobin is an example of a protein with:
questions.explanation: Hemoglobin has quaternary structure, consisting of four polypeptide subunits (two α and two β chains) that assemble together.

questions.question_text: Denaturation of a protein involves:
options: B. Loss of higher-order structure while keeping primary structure
questions.explanation: Denaturation disrupts secondary, tertiary, and quaternary structure through loss of non-covalent interactions, but primary structure (peptide bonds) remains intact.

questions.question_text: Enzymes are biological catalysts that are typically:
questions.explanation: Most enzymes are proteins (some RNA molecules called ribozymes also have catalytic activity). Their specific 3D structure enables catalysis.

questions.question_text: Prosthetic groups in proteins are:
options: B. Tightly bound non-protein components required for function
questions.explanation: Prosthetic groups are non-protein molecules permanently or tightly bound to proteins, essential for their function (e.g., heme in hemoglobin).
